results.title: Butterfly
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1976-1980 Olympic & world class swimmers”.
One of a series of films which shows swimmers, and their styles and techniques. Slow motion is used to clarify the demonstrations. This film concentrates on butterfly swimming. Swimmers featured include Mike Bruner, Steve Gregg and Joe Bottom.

results.title: Breaking through...
results.creator_credit: Jackie McKimmie, Richard Mason and Alfred Road Films
results.brief_description: Cathy Ann Matthews had only pleasant and peaceful recollections of her childhood. Not until her own daughter was getting married did the memories of the past come flooding back. This sensitive and moving docu-drama is about a woman coming to terms with the horrible abuse she went through as a child and deals with the way these memories flooded her mind until she became almost suicidal. Stars Deidre Rubenstein, Tony Barry, Gabrielle Mason, Julie Hamilton and Noni Hazlehurst. Based on the book ‘Breaking though: no longer a victim of child abuse’ by Cathy Ann Matthews.

results.title: Breaking through (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Kristen Dunphy, Margaret Lupton and Megan Heyward
results.brief_description: Produced for the Australian Deafness Council, this informative and supportive video encourages deaf students to look positively at a broad range of jobs which they may not have considered. It shows young deaf people at work in a wide variety of fields from professional to unskilled, and looks at some of the problems they may encounter.

results.title: Breaking the ice
results.brief_description: Tim Bowden takes us on one of the last greatest adventures - a voyage to the Australian Antarctic Territory in this spectacular 6 part travel series. Over a period of 2 months Tim visited all 4 of Australia’s Antarctic stations at Macquarie Island Casey, Davis and Mawson. The result is a fascinating ‘behind the scenes’ look at what Australians are doing in Antarctica - a wild and beautiful icy wilderness that has attracted adventurers and scientists since the days of Scott, Shackleton and Mawson. Highlight include spectacular views of Australia’s only ice-breaking ship “Aurora Australis” charging through the pack ice, a visit to a new Emperor Penguin colony the day after it was discovered and superb footage of penguins, elephant seals and albatrosses on sub-Antarctic Macquarie Island.

results.title: Breakdown
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of a young woman’s schizophrenic breakdown, and of her recovery in a modern mental hospital. Inherent in the film is an appeal for greater public understanding of mental illness and for the removal of the stigma that still surrounds it. The film presents the case of a seemingly well-adjusted young woman, showing the disintegration of her personality and the psychiatric treatment that follows.

results.title: Breaking bows & arrows = Breaking bows and arrows
results.creator_credit: Liz Thompson, Ellenor Cox, Firelight Film and Tiger Eye
results.brief_description: On the island of Bougainville in Papua New Guinea, thousands of people were killed in a war of secession that grew from a local uprising against the Australian copper company CRA. The Bougainville Revolutionary Army was pitted against Papua New Guinean military forces, funded and trained by the Australian government. When the ten-year-old civil war ended in 1998, the islanders had to deal with the legacy of conflict between neighbours and begin to confront the challenging emotional terrain of personal reconciliation. “Breaking bows and arrows” documents the islanders’ road to forgiveness and healing, a process governed by their own cultural tradition. Traditional ceremonies and rituals played a powerful role in the reconciliation process, bringing together both victims and perpetrators in an attempt to heal the deep emotional wounds and reverse the legacy of anger, pain, and revenge. A powerful documentary that demonstrates that the path to true reconciliation begins with forgiveness. Teachers notes are available at http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs.

results.title: Breakdown
results.creator_credit: Peter Thurley, Vladimir Valenta and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fictional film about two people and a salamander. The car they are travelling in collapses unceremoniously on the road to Montreal. Finding a mechanic in the quiet countryside is never easy, but here the problem is compounded by linguistic misunderstandings. Eventually the car runs again, but one of the passengers refuses to run along.

results.title: Bread and roses
results.creator_credit: Gaylene Preston, Robin Laing and Preston-Laing Productions
results.brief_description: Originally made for television, this is a drama in four parts based on the autobiography of Sonja Davies, New Zealand activist and parliamentarian. It spans 20 years- beginning during World War II when Sonja falls in love with an American Soldier. Pregnant and unwed, Sonja learns that he will not return and once her daughter Penny is born, she returns to nursing to support her. In illness she is reunited with an old boyfriend, Charlie, who aids her recovery. Together they experience great difficulties with shortsighted officialdom, and in response become actively involved in local politics. Sonja particularly finds political strength amongst women and socialist sympathisers, and together they embark on a struggle to ensure that others will share the peace and prosperity of a post war New Zealand. Cast includes Genevieve Picot, Mick Rose, Donna Akersten, Tina Regtien and Erik Thompson.

results.title: Bran nue dae
results.creator_credit: Jimmy Chi, Tom Zubrycki and Bran Nue Dae Productions
results.brief_description: An inspirational film on the production of the Aboriginal musical ‘Bran Nue Dae’ and the life of Jimmy Chi, its creator. Chi has suffered from schizophrenia since he was a university student but remains undaunted by his illness. ‘Bran Nue Dae’ is largely the work of Chi with the pooled talents of Broome band, Knuckles. The musical is a story of an Aboriginal boy’s flight from the city of Perth to his homeland at Djaridjin. His journey in search of identity, love and security takes us across the state in a blend of rock-opera, road-movie, comedy, song, dance, and romance.
